good morning everybody Thank You Adrian so machine learning is experiencing something of a renaissance at the moment
and that's primarily because we're able to now overcome the single largest problem which has held back machine
learning scale the challenge for machine learning almost always revolves are an

amount of compute required to actually run those training models and train up the models correctly is considerable and
not to be overlooked the compute requirements for inferring predictions against those trained models is also
vast and large particularly at scale but at AWS we've been addressing these
challenges of scale for customers for over a decade so we have customers today that have exabytes petabytes of data as

as aggressively as possible up onto AWS and all new data that's being generated whether it's from mobile applications

we have tons of GPUs you can spin up current generation GPUs and our next

as an example of this we worked with Stanford to try and help patients who
are suffering from diabetic blindness diabetic blindness is the leading cause of blindness for men between the ages of
21 and 46 in the United States and it's preventable in almost all cases if you
can catch it early the challenge is that identifying it requires looking at photos like this this is a thunderscope
it's a picture of the back of the eye and what you're looking for are very very small changes in the vasculature at
the back of the eye and today humans have to look at these images requires continual attention it's very expensive
it's very inaccurate and the cost of missing a diagnosis is extremely high for the patients so we were able to take
pictures of healthy eyes we were able to take pictures of unhealthy eyes and train a deep learning system with our
colleagues at Stanford that was able to predict and reduce the chance of diabetic blindness in 90% of cases we're
